Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Correlated Exciton Fluctuations in Natural and Artificial Light Harvesting Antennae
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Andrew Moran and his research group at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill will study how large assemblies of molecules absorb light, and transfer the energy from one part of the assembly to another. They will focus specifically on the role of spatially correlated nuclear motion in light harvesting mechanisms. The study will obtain information about atomic and molecular motions on very short time scales using a femtosecond laser technique called two-dimensional photon echo spectroscopy (2D-PES). In addition, Prof. Moran and his team will develop a new technique called intraband electronic coherence spectroscopy (IECS), which will provide more detailed information about the mechanisms controlling energy transfer processes. The systems to be studied include light harvesting phycobilisomes, which are protein structures in cyanobacteria, as well as artificial cyanine dye aggregates, whose readily controlled shapes make them excellent models for exploring structure-function relationships.

This research project will advance our fundamental understanding of photochemical processes, and also have implications for the biological sciences (e.g., photosynthesis) and sustainable energy technology. The research program will be fertile ground for undergraduate and graduate students. Many of the optical components used in the experiments are/will be built by graduate students. This hands-on experience represents a unique opportunity for chemists to obtain an interdisciplinary expertise in advanced methods of ultrafast science. Undergraduates will contribute by preparing the nanostructured aggregates that will be studied using 2D-PES and IECS. As part of the Project Seed Program, high school students will participate in the research program. For example, they will use computer simulations to design pigment complexes and simulate their absorption spectra. In addition, Prof. Moran and his team will conduct laboratory demonstrations for a Pre-College program administered by the School of Education at the University of North Carolina. The goal of the Pre-College program is to broaden the pool of students pursuing mathematics and science based majors and careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of the award titled “Correlated Exciton Fluctuations in Natural and Artificial Light Harvesting Antennae” was to investigate energy transport mechanisms in molecular aggregates, photosynthetic complexes, and DNA components using newly developed multidimensional spectroscopies. Applications in the deep ultraviolet and visible regions of the spectrum are summarized below. Outreach activities are also described.

Fourier transform two-dimensional photon echo spectroscopies were first applied and matured most rapidly at infrared wavelengths, although such experiments are now routinely conducted using visible laser pulses. Further progress “from NMR to X-rays” must contend with several technical challenges encountered in the deep UV spectral range (200-300 nm). The PI’s research group addressed many of these challenges in the development of a two-dimensional photon echo experiment operational in the 270-nm wavelength range with sub-20-fs time resolution. This setup was used in some of the first studies of DNA nucleobases at cryogenic temperatures with femtosecond time resolution. Most recently, vibrational coherences associated with the ring opening processes of cyclohexadiene derivative, α-terpinene, were detected.

Experiments conducted with visible light targeted two cyanobacterial light harvesting proteins, allophyocyanin and C-phycocyanin. The energy transfer rate between pigments is roughly 10 times faster in allophycocyanin than it is in C-phycocyanin despite the nearly identical structures found in the two systems. The PI’s experiments and model calculations suggest that this difference in behavior originates in vibrational motions which had been neglected in earlier quantum mechanical models for these systems. In effect, the quantum states, termed “vibronic excitons”, mix electronic and vibrational degrees of freedom. These surprising insights influenced theoretical descriptions of light harvesting dynamics in other proteins.

The PI’s research group participated in outreach activities during the summer. The main contribution was to a “Summer Academy” camp organized by the Pre-College Program within the School of Education at UNC. Approximately 45 middle school and high school students attended this program each summer. Undergraduate and graduate students in the PI’s research group gave talks to the Summer Academy students about their research and supervised hands-on laboratory exercises (e.g., light harvesting, principles of telescopes). The PI’s group interacted with approximately 200 students through this program.
